p: Lirong Cui is professor in School of Management & Economics, Beijing Institute of Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree in Statistics from University of Wales, UK in 1994. He has worked on reliability related problems since 1986. Several papers and technique reports have been published. Recently, he also coauthored of a book on reliability. His recent research interests are stochastic modeling, quality and reliability engineering, simulation and optimization, software development for quality and reliability, operations research and applications of probability and statistics in various fields.

p: Way Kuo is University Distinguished Professor and Dean of Engineering, Professor of Industrial and Information Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, and Statistics and Management Science at The University of Tennessee, and an Honorary Professor of National Chiao Tung University in Taiwan. Previously, he was holder of Wisenbaker Chair of Engineering in Innovation and Executive Associate Dean of Engineering at Texas A&M University and was with Bell Labs and Iowa State University. In 1991, he was appointed Senior Fulbright Scholar in Reliability to Lisbon and Glasgow. He is an elected member of the National Academy of Engineering, Academia Sinica (National Academy of Science), Republic of China, and International Academy for Quality, Fellow of IIE, IEEE, and ASQ. Dr. Kuo currently serves as the chief editor of IEEE Transactions on Reliability. He is an author of several books on reliability and quality engineering.

H.T. Loh received his Ph.D. from University of Michigan. He has received extensive funding for several projects in these areas from government and industry. Prof Loh has published more than 60 journal/conference papers. Prof Loh is the Deputy Director of the Design Technology Institute which focuses on the development of predictive tools for product/process quality and reliability.

M. Xie received his Ph.D. in quality technology from Linkoping University in 1987. He has been active in research in the area of reliability, quality and engineering statistics. He is an author of numerous papers and three books and on the editorial board of several international journals. He is a senior member of IEEE and ASQ.

details.abstract: The effect of a repair of a complex system can usually be approximated by the following two types: minimal repair for which the system is restored to its functioning state with minimum effort, or perfect repair for which the system is replaced or repaired to a good-as-new state. When both types of repair are possible, an important problem is to determine the repair policy; that is, the type of repair which should be carried out after a failure. In this paper, an optimal allocation problem is studied for a monotonic failure rate repairable system under some resource constraints. In the first model, the numbers of minimal & perfect repairs are fixed, and the optimal repair policy maximizing the expected system lifetime is studied. In the second model, the total amount of repair resource is fixed, and the costs of each minimal & perfect repair are assumed to be known. The optimal allocation algorithm is derived in this case. Two numerical examples are shown to illustrate the procedures.

For a repairable system undergoing minimal repair, the optimal replacement time under the age replacement policy is discussed.
